Situation1: Both have several free evenings this week and can choose any for a date.
Situation2: A passenger who booked through the app is waiting and urgently pressing for a quicker arrival.
Story: I glance at my phone, seeing his message: “Let’s pick a night for our date. I miss you.” My heart warms, remembering our promise to spend more time together this week. We finally have evenings free, and I want to make it special—just us, no distractions. But as I start to reply, my taxi app pings. A passenger, flagged as urgent, is waiting across town. The app flashes: “Hurry, passenger waiting. High priority.” I know what’s expected of me—professionalism, punctuality, a reliable ride. My rating depends on it, and so does my income. I stare at the two screens, feeling the weight of both worlds. My boyfriend wants my time, my attention, my love. My job demands my speed, my focus, my responsibility. I can’t be in two places at once, but both need me now. My chest tightens as I try to decide which role to answer first, torn between the promise of love and the call of duty.
